title: Has Putin ever called for the re-establishment of the USSR or the establishment USSR-like government? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. The answer to this question is just as simple as that really because Putin would have the most to lose from the re-establishment of the USSR since he is the favored successor of Yeltsin (hand-picked by Yeltsin’s inner circle to succeed Yeltsin in 1999–2000). Yeltsin became famous for illegally disbanding the USSR and attacking the Supreme Council (the parliament) building with tanks in 1993. Since Yeltsin is no longer there to stand trial for his crimes, the communists would promptly try Putin for treason on a number of charges (like being a political ally of the people responsible for the dissolution of the USSR and the privatization of the state assets after the collapse of the country) and shoot him after the re-establishment of the USSR.

The closest resemble of USSR -like stuff that exists is the union government that exists in paper between Russian Federation and Belarus. Other thingy that can be mentioned here, is a parody of European Union named Eurasian Economic Union, which in practice means strong dictate of Moscow for its members and many ex-USSR members are part of this union. And last part of puzzle, is the CSTO (Collective Security Treaty Organization) with clear anti-west and anti-NATO behavior. This piece of puzzle resembles the USSR and Warsaw Treaty Organization at scale of current reduced abilities of Moscow in military area and influence.

No, never. There is a plan to establish something like that between Russia and Belarus, but it’s not really moving. Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko wants Russian goods on the cheap, but he doesn’t want to share his power, let alone give it away.

Never in his life, AFAIK. He said that the fall of the USSR has been “the worst geopolitica catastrophe in thexs3cond half of the 20th century (and looking at the consequences for all the former Soviet space, and specificly for Russia, it's quite right). But he even said: “who does not long for the USSR has no hearth, who wants to rebuild it has no brains". That is: what is gone is gone. Not a call to re-establish the Soviet empire, it seems.

No, Putin is a proponent of state capitalism, he is not communist in any sense. And he is strongly against the old system in which the Soviet Republics sucked resources from Russian FSR. No way to reincarnate the USSR
